awd_titl_txt: The National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Activities Supported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
awd_abstract_narration:
This is the Basic Ordering Agreement (Task Order) supports the National Center for Atmospheric Research activities funded by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report represents projects that are funded by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). The project "Modeling Air Quality Impacts Associated with Wildfires in the Western United States," significantly advanced our understanding of wildfire-related air pollution and its public health effects. This project, conducted by NSF NCAR, utilized sophisticated modeling techniques to simulate the distribution of pollutants from wildfire smoke across various regions and time periods, specifically targeting states in the western U.S.

Intellectual Merit

The project focused on using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model coupled with Chemistry (WRF-Chem) to capture air quality changes resulting from wildfire emissions. Researchers simulated pollutants like carbon monoxide (CO), black carbon (BC), ozone, and fine particulate matter (PM2.5) on a 4-km grid resolution, covering the years 2005 to 2020. These pollutants were traced back to wildfire sources, allowing the team to isolate the impact of wildfire smoke on air quality across individual geographic areas. By integrating WRF-Chem with MOZART (Model for Ozone and Related Tracers) and MOSAIC (Module for Simulating Aerosol Interactions and Chemistry), the team provided highly accurate daily data on pollutant concentrations.

A notable achievement was refining exposure-response functions to connect wildfire smoke levels with health outcomes. For example, statistical analyses revealed a link between PM2.5 exposure and increased mortality, particularly in adults aged 65 and older, with an estimated 3,180 annual premature deaths in the western U.S. attributable to wildfire-related pollution. This finding contributes significantly to epidemiology and public health, illustrating the severe impact of wildfire smoke on vulnerable populations.

Broader Impacts

This project provided actionable data for both public health and environmental stakeholders. The results were shared with CDC collaborators and were integrated into public health models assessing wildfire impacts on health outcomes like hospitalizations and medication refills. Additionally, the project data was made available in a public-facing dashboard to educate the public on the health risks posed by wildfire smoke, particularly on a county level. This tool serves as a resource for communities and agencies to understand local air quality issues and prepare more effectively for wildfire seasons.

The collaboration between NCAR and the CDC extended the reach of atmospheric science into public health, creating opportunities for interdisciplinary knowledge sharing. The findings have been disseminated through various platforms, including conferences in atmospheric science and environmental epidemiology, and are slated for publication in a special issue of Environmental Research: Health. The project also serves as a basis for future proposals, demonstrating its foundational role in ongoing wildfire health impact research.

In conclusion, this project bridged critical gaps between atmospheric science and public health, providing valuable insights and tools to better understand and mitigate the effects of wildfire-related air pollution on communities.
